channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in New Zealand on 24 May
item.description: No new cases of Covid-19, two pubs shut down for failing to comply with restrictions, travel agents plead for patience and Avatar filming to resume in NZ.

item.title: Covid-19: Trans NZers unable to get gender-affirming healthcare
item.description: For some trans and non-binary New Zealanders, Covid-19 has prevented them gaining access to gender-affirming healthcare.

item.title: Don't leave us with no hope, Filipino migrants plead
item.description: The Queenstown Association of Migrant Pinoys says more than 500 Filipino migrants have sought welfare support in the resort town.

item.title: Avatar producer Jon Landau on his return to New Zealand
item.description: The producer of the Avatar sci-fi movie sequels says he has no qualms coming back to New Zealand during the Covid-19 recovery phase.

item.title: Bad weather affects search for missing trampers in Kahurangi National Park
item.description: All but one of the teams searching for two trampers lost in the Kahurangi National Park have been pulled back due to bad weather.

item.title: Auckland Airport shelves most of $1.2 billion of works
item.description: Auckland Airport has put most of a $1.2 billion work project on ice, but will shorten its runway by more than a kilometre tonight as one project goes ahead.

item.title: Eid al-Fitr: 'Everyone is finding their own little ways of celebrating'
item.description: First person: Auckland University student Zainab Baba talks about how this year's Eid celebrations to mark the end of the fasting month of Ramadan will be very different.

item.title: No new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand for second day in row
item.description: There have been no new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand in the past 24 hours, for the second day running.

item.title: Two Auckland pubs shut down for breaching level two restrictions
item.description: Two pubs in Auckland were shut down last night, for failing to comply with restrictions under Covid alert level two.

item.title: Man's body found down cliff at Cape Farewell
item.description: A man's body has been successfully recovered from a cliff face at the top of the South Island.

item.title: Christchurch residents give council its lowest rating
item.description: Christchurch City Council has received its worst ever mark for performance.

item.title: Long winter ahead for Te Anau after two crises
item.description: With a population of about 2500, tourism and visitor spend contributes hugely to the Te Anau economy; the compounded impact of the February storm and Covid-19 has left businesses in a tough position.

item.title: Hunua Falls searchers stood down in hunt for woman
item.description: Police are confident searchers have scoured the Hunua Falls area where a missing woman's car was found, and will not continue to search the area.

item.title: Heavy rain forecast for most of NZ on Sunday and Monday
item.description: Heavy rain is expected in central New Zealand from tomorrow afternoon and most will see rain on Monday.

item.title: NZ govt concerned over China's security law for Hong Kong
item.description: The New Zealand government has joined a chorus of international concern about China's plan to impose a national security law on Hong Kong.

item.title: Covid-19: What happened in NZ and around the world on 23 May
item.description: Today's Covid-19 developments include news about a New Zealand vaccine venture, a lauded celebrity cat, problems getting shearing gangs, and a warning against Trump's favoured medicine of choice.

item.title: Kiwi company 'cautiously optimistic' on developing Covid-19 vaccine
item.description: A New Zealand company says it's early days, but it's cautiously optimistic about its chances of developing a Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: No new cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand today
item.description: There have been no new cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, the Health Ministry has confirmed.
